title: Trump Hopes to Stem Tide of Legal Setbacks on Health Care
summary: A hearing this week on a lawsuit to topple the Affordable Care Act is the latest test. title: Eric Swalwell Drops Out of Presidential Race
summary: California congressman, struggling with fundraising and support, becomes first Democrat to depart crowded field. Rep. summary: The regulators protect web giants by blocking local TV mergers.. Google and Facebook are squeezing local news by gobbling up more and more advertising dollars. title: The Treaty Behind China's Drone Edge
summary: Beijing isn't a signatory of the 1987 pact, so it's been exporting UAVs to American allies.. It also shows how ubiquitous and necessary unmanned aerial vehicles have become for America's military missions. Yet the U.S. may cede the future of these large UAVs to competitors such as China, Russia and, ironically, Iran, if we don't change how we develop and deploy these systems.

title: The Myth of Monetary Stimulus Is Unraveling
summary: Central bankers around the world are admitting that low interest rates can't sustain real growth.. title: Adam Smith's Refreshing Idea of Justice
summary: His definition attempts to minimize harm while maximizing freedom.. In a world full of people looking to impose their concepts of justice on others, it's refreshing to revisit Adam Smith's thinking. One of the best-known quotations from "The Wealth of Nations" (1776) defines natural liberty: "Every man, as long as he does not violate the laws of justice, is left perfectly free to pursue his own interest his own way, and to bring both his industry and capital into competition with those of any other man."

title: Why U.S. Women Rule the World

summary: The Congressional Budget Office puts the toll at 1.3 million to 3.7 million.. This is one political promise it's OK to break. title: 'For the Good of the Game' Review: The Commish Remembers
summary: Two subjects dominate Bud Selig's account of his tenure: baseball's troubled labor relations and its slow response to the use of steroids.. Whatever happens in tonight's All-Star Game in Cleveland, it is unlikely to approach the fiasco of the 2002 All-Star Game in Milwaukee, when both teams ran out of pitchers in extra innings and the commissioner of baseball took it upon himself to declare the game over-a tie. Angry fans threw beer bottles down on the field and chanted "Bud Must Go." The "Bud" of that inglorious moment was Bud Selig, whose memoir, "For the Good of the Game," traces his "lifelong love affair" with baseball, including his tenure as commissioner, from 1992 to 2015, a period in which baseball underwent dramatic changes, not always for the better. On Mr. Selig's personal score card, the hits far outnumber the errors.

title: Nationalism Is Necessary but Insufficient
summary: Trump's approach helps win allies in Asia. But it isn't a basis for world order.. As President Trump reveled in air-force flyovers and a tank display this Fourth of July, the idea that dominates his administration's domestic and foreign policies was on full display. That idea is nationalism, and Mr. Trump hopes it will reshape both American politics and the international order.

summary: Federal prosecutors allege former asset manager ran an operation that allowed him to sexually exploit dozens of girls. Financier Jeffrey Epstein was indicted in New York on federal sex-trafficking charges stemming from an alleged scheme to exploit underage girls, another chapter in a lurid legal drama that has surrounded the politically connected money manager for years.

title: Instagram Introduces New Anti-Bullying Features
summary: One feature, Restrict, allows users to limit their reactions with those who target them; another prompts users to reconsider posts detected as offensive. Instagram is rolling out new features to help combat cyberbullying, as the social-media company and its parent, Facebook Inc., work to quell criticism related to harassment on their platforms.

title: Palestinian Leadership Doesn't Want a Deal
summary: The Marshall Plan worked because the recipients of the aid were willing participants. The Palestinians not only refuse to accept the Trump aid plan but even imprison and harass those Arabs who are willing to listen to the Trump proposals.. Glenn Hubbard is delusional if he thinks "The Promise Of Trump's Mideast Plan" (op-ed, July 2) will be successful. The Marshall Plan worked because the recipients of the aid were willing participants. The Palestinians not only refuse to accept the aid plan but imprison and harass Arabs willing to listen to the Trump proposals. The Marshall Plan assisted capitalist nations to rebuild after World War II. In the Middle East we are dealing with ideology and religious fanaticism far more powerful than economic needs. We made this mistake in Iraq and President Trump is making the same mistake. Many in Israel also believe that economic needs will rule over religion. The 19 hijackers on 9/11 were middle- to upper-class Muslims. Poverty didn't motivate their attack on New York and Washington.

title: Arkes vs. Alito on Free Speech and Relativism
summary: For Justice Kagan "viewpoint neutrality" evidently means that we must treat, on the same moral plane, the killing of the innocent and the opposition to the killing of the innocent. If that is not "moral relativism," words have lost their meaning.. I appreciate the good-natured jibing of my friends at the Journal over the outcome of Iancu v. Brunetti on obscenities in the titles of corporations ("'Scandalous' Speech Is Protected," Review & Outlook, June 25). You pay me the compliment of noting that Justice Samuel Alito's concurring opinion was written in part as a letter to me. As it turned out, he accepted a critical part of my argument, and yet he also insisted that "our decision is not based on moral relativism." But I'm afraid that assurance was instantly embarrassed by this jarring passage in Justice Elena Kagan's opinion for the Court: The Patent and Trademark Office, she said, had "rejected marks reflecting support for al-Qaeda (Baby Al Qaeda and al-Qaeda on T-shirts) 'because the bombing of civilians and other terrorist acts are shocking to the sense of decency and call out for condemnation.' . . . Yet it approved registration of a mark with the words War on Terror Memorial."

title: Doomsday Math Neither Accurate or Helpful
summary: William Poundstone says that "statistically there is an equal, 50% chance that we are in the first half or the last half." But this conclusion assumes that the list is finite because it is meaningless to speak of the first or last half of an infinite list.. I don't know whether humanity is doomed, but I do know that the techniques that were used to deal with "the German tank problem" cannot logically be applied to the question of the long-term survival of the human race ("The Unsettling Possibilities of 'Doomsday' Math," Review, June 29). The Allied statisticians who were trying to figure out how many German tanks would counter the D-Day invasion knew, for a certainty, that the Germans had a finite number of tanks. William Poundstone says (correctly) that "no one alive knows how long the list is" of all persons who have lived, are living and will live. He therefore concludes that "statistically there is an equal, 50% chance that we are in the first half or the last half." But this conclusion assumes that the list is finite because it is meaningless to speak of the first or last half of an infinite list. And the assumption that the list is finite contradicts the premise that no one alive knows how long the list is. Unlike German tanks at a particular moment in time, human beings over the entire course of human history-past, present and future-might conceivably be infinite in number.

title: The Noncompete Agreement Is Now Ridiculously Abused
summary: Noncompetes were originated for high-income, high-information executives, and they have been used for sandwich makers in sub shops. It is absolutely ridiculous.. Noncompete agreements without compensation for the time you don't compete are wrong and should be outlawed ("Noncompete Pacts Spread to Interns," U.S. News, July 1). I agree that companies have secrets to protect, but workers have bills to pay and need to earn money. Noncompetes were originated for high-income, high-information executives, and they have been used for sandwich makers in sub shops. It is absolutely ridiculous.

title: Fed Expectations Trigger Record Run of Outflows in Leveraged Loans

title: MTA Warned Years Ago of Rotting Wood on Elevated Subway Line
summary: Wood was flagged as deficient in October 2015 and requiring replacement 'as soon as is practicable'.

title: New York's Top Financial Regulator Wants to Protect Consumers
summary: Linda Lacewell said she would step up to police everything from financial marketing to online lending. New York's new financial services regulator said her focus will be on ensuring data privacy and consumer protection as she takes the reins of an eight-year-old agency.

title: The Inside Story of Kim Kardashian West's Billion-Dollar Shapewear Bet
summary: Kim Kardashian West has long dreamed of her own body-positive, shade-inclusive line of shapewear and underwear. But now the outcry over the erstwhile Kimono's name could derail many months of planning. How she and a team of blue-chip investors are trying to salvage their claim to a piece of the $83 billion industry.. It was around noon on Friday, June 28, when Kim Kardashian West realized it was time to cave. After three days of being globally thrashed, she would have to change the name of her latest venture, a shapewear and lingerie line, a concept she had been thinking about for the past decade-longer than she had been married to Kanye West, longer than her four kids had been alive, longer than she had been arguably the most famous woman in the world other than Queen Elizabeth II. The name Kimono had to go.

title: Bank Stocks Haven't Priced In Enough Bad News
summary: Bank stocks appear cheap based on analyst estimates for future earnings, but are analysts pessimistic enough?. American bank stocks look cheap right now, but are they cheap enough? That depends on how bad things get when the economic cycle turns.

title: Bregal Sagemount Invests in Buyers Edge Platform
summary: It is the firm's eighth investment in the supply chain technology-enabled logistics sector. Private-equity firm Bregal Sagemount is betting once again on the supply-chain software sector with a growth investment in Buyers Edge Platform LLC, a group purchasing and technology company for the food service industry.

title: After Election Defeat, Greek Leader Promises to Influence Politics
summary: Whether Alexis Tsipras returns to his populist roots or moves closer to the center-left could offer insight into how politics in Europe will play out. ATHENS-Alexis Tsipras, the former enfant terrible of European politics, must reinvent himself in opposition after losing power in Greece's elections.

title: Job-Interview Etiquette Isn't Just for the Applicants
summary: In a tight hiring market, it's more important than ever for employers to avoid poor behavior like ghosting job seekers after meeting with them. Employers are battling to hire skilled employees in one of the tightest labor markets in 50 years. So they must be courting job seekers, wooing them with care and consideration-right?

title: At Zappos, Algorithms Teach Themselves
summary: 'Genetic algorithms,' which mimic natural selection, learn to understand what customers are searching for and spit out better results. Zappos LLC, an online seller of shoes and apparel, said a self-learning algorithm has shown promise in solving one of its most perplexing search-engine issues: irrelevant results.

title: Car-Sharing Startup Getaround Bets on Ride Sharing With SoftBank
summary: Getaround trails its rival Turo, but has tied itself to SoftBank's transportation strategy. Nearly a year after it raised a $300 million investment led by SoftBank Group Corp.'s Vision Fund, car-sharing startup Getaround Inc. is hoping to profit from ties to the tech giant's other portfolio companies.

title: Getaround, Turo Take Different Car-Rental Routes
summary: Startups both offer tools that let car-owners rent out their vehicles for short periods. Getaround Inc.'s car-sharing app allows urban customers who need a car for a day or a few hours to rent from nearby car owners-and now it wants to take that model to more cities.

title: Carnival, Under Court Order, Gives Compliance Unit More Independence
summary: Cruise line operator is expected to name its first chief compliance officer soon as it takes steps to remedy recent environmental lapses. When Carnival Corp. names its first chief compliance officer, as it is expected to do soon, the appointment will be a symbolic step in the cruise-line operator's effort to move on from years of legal woes.

title: Missing Spending Stimulus Weighs On U.S. Growth
summary: Economists expected greater boost after 2018 budget deal; muted growth only partly explained by lagging federal outlays. WASHINGTON-The economy was supposed to get a lift this year from higher government spending enacted in 2018, but so far much of that stimulus hasn't shown up, puzzling economists.

title: China's Financial Plumbing Is Getting Leakier
summary: Money-markets ructions expose a vulnerability that still hasn't been patched: dependence on low-quality collateral. Markets are a psychological phenomenon-a set of beliefs about how the world works and what things are worth. When assumptions are challenged, the results can be stomach-churning.

title: Conservatives Regain Control in Greece
summary: Voters' return to a mainstream political party after trying the populist Syriza shows that the rise of antiestablishment parties can also be reversed. ATHENS-Greece elected a conservative government on a promise to cut taxes and spur economic growth, initial results showed, ejecting a left-wing government that couldn't deliver an end to the country's long economic slump.

title: Large IPOs Set Record Pace in First Half
summary: Startups raised $472 million in capital on average through their public offerings, data show. The number of companies valued at $10 billion or more that have gone public in the first half of this year is more than at any other time since the dot-com boom of 2000, data show.

title: John Derian's Favorite Things
summary: The decoupage artist and visionary retailer on the paintings, stone cactus and coffee cup he treasures most.. "The boy on the bottom right is a pencil drawing from the 1700s. There's something about him that I always felt connected to, like somehow he's me in a funny way. The painting above it reminds me of life drawing classes, of sitting and drawing. The guy to the left is a little street urchin. There's something so charming about his hat. Somebody cut out paper patterns of animals in the one below. They're inspiring to my own work. In front of that is this cactus I got in Paris. It's stone but it looks lifelike in person; it kind of tricks everybody. Plus I like fake things, so it does a lot for me.

title: How Project Runway's Brandon Maxwell Became a Gaga-Approved Success
summary: A whirlwind day with the CFDA Womenswear Designer of the Year.. OH, WHAT A PAGEANT GIRL I've become," says designer Brandon Maxwell, 34, fixing his blowout and dabbing his makeup as he preps to film a segment for an upcoming episode of CBS Sunday Morning. It's just before noon on the last Friday in May on the set of Maxwell's pre-spring 2020 lookbook shoot. Roughly 30 people and one French bulldog, Stella Marie, are assembled at Pier59 Studios in Manhattan to shoot the collection before Maxwell and his fiancé, Jessy Price, have to catch a flight to Houston for Price's sister's high school graduation.

title: Letter From the Editor: Web Friendly
summary: In her monthly editor's letter, WSJ.'s Kristina O'Neill introduces an all-digital issue.. As The Wall Street Journal embarks on a new partnership with Apple News+ this summer, it seems an ideal moment to present an all-digital issue of WSJ. Magazine. We're very excited to bring you this first-ever mobile-first edition, conveniently starring a celebrity with a reputation for breaking the internet, as well as a rising Hollywood star who's becoming a household name in her own right.

title: David Harbour, Charli XCX and Niecy Nash on the Moment When Everything Changed
summary: Those luminaries and more weigh in on this month's Columnists topic: Turning Points. "When we started [the podcast] Criminal, it was a total passion project. I mean, it was just an idea that you didn't know if it would work. We wanted to create something brand new that we could control, a concept that we could design: the sound of the show, the look of the show [and] the topic. I remember working hard on this for months and months, and we put out the first episode. That first day, 50 people listened. And I thought to myself, OK, 50 people, that's my family, our friends. I have a network of 50 people. But then I remember, I saw that 51 people had listened, and I thought, OK, someone who I don't know has found this thing. It worked and that was it. Criminal has millions of listeners a month now. But for me, I still think about looking at that download number and seeing that one person. The 51st person to ever listen to Criminal, in my mind, will be the most important thing, because it was when I realized that this thing was reaching someone who hadn't been forced to listen."

title: Contributors to WSJ. Magazine's First All-Digital Issue
summary: Writer Molly Lambert contributed to this issue of the magazine.. For WSJ. Magazine's first all-digital issue, writer Molly Lambert profiled rapper and actress Awkwafina. "She was so cool, I felt like I already knew her when we met," says Lambert. The best part of working on the story, she explains, was talking to Awkwafina about magic. "We shared stories about amateur close-up magic and being home hobbyists," she says.

title: The U.S. Is Overflowing With Natural Gas. Not Everyone Can Get It.
summary: U.S. gas production is at a record high, but the infrastructure needed to move the fuel around the country hasn't kept up. America is awash in natural gas. In parts of the country there's hardly a drop to burn.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: A New Team of Government Lawyers Will Take Over Census Fight
summary: President Trump says Attorney General Barr is exploring 'a couple of avenues' for adding the citizenship question. A new team of government lawyers will be taking charge of the census fight, the Justice Department said, as the Trump administration continues to search for a legally acceptable way to include a citizenship question in the 2020 survey despite a recent Supreme Court decision barring it.

title: U.S. Oil Prices Rise as Busy Week of Reports Kicks Off
summary: Reports could provide direction on global demand, production from U.S. and OPEC. U.S. oil prices pushed higher on Monday as crude continued to dig out from a nearly 5% loss suffered last Tuesday.

title: Incoming Top Naval Officer Will Retire Amid Ethics Scrutiny
summary: Adm. William Moran will step down rather than take over as Chief of Naval Operations. WASHINGTON-Adm. William Moran, who was to take over as the Navy's top officer this summer, is instead stepping down over his association with a former naval officer who had been investigated more than two years ago for inappropriate conduct, U.S. military officials said.

title: Deutsche Bank to Exit Global Equities, Trading Business
summary: German bank will cut 18,000 jobs by 2022 and will focus on serving European companies and retail-banking customers, including wealthy clients. Deutsche Bank AG moved Sunday to gut its global ambitions as a trading powerhouse, cutting 18,000 jobs and retreating to its German banking roots in a radical overhaul to try to save itself after years of decline.

title: 130 Years of History as Seen in the Pages of The Wall Street Journal
summary: A special report highlighting how the Journal has covered some of the most significant events in the world since its debut in 1889. To Our Readers:

title: California Tallies Damage From Quakes
summary: As residents braced for more aftershocks the governor asked Trump for federal aid. TRONA, Calif.-As Californians braced for aftershocks from a pair of powerful earthquakes that hit late last week, officials began the arduous work of assessing the damage to roads, buildings and pipelines spread over a massive and sparsely populated area between Las Vegas and Los Angeles.
